statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Rob Ferguson grabbed the airball and put it back with 2.2 seconds left to give the Hawks a 59-57 win over the Owls on Sunday at the Palestra.
article.headline: No cheap shots as Saint Joseph's edges Temple
article.linkText: No cheap shots as Saint Joseph's edges Temple
article.story:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) -- No one took any cheap shots or was called a goon. Saint Joseph's and Temple made this one memorable because of a thrilling finish.

Abdulai Jalloh forced a shot in traffic from the left side, but Rob Ferguson grabbed the airball and put it back with 2.2 seconds left to give the Hawks a 59-57 win over the Owls on Sunday at the Palestra.

"It was a hell of a game," Temple coach John Chaney said. "Both teams played well, played extremely well."

There was no sign of any carry-over from either school in their first matchup since last year's infamous game when Chaney sent in Nehemiah Ingram to commit hard fouls that resulted in a broken arm for Saint Joseph's John Bryant.

Chaney used the 6-foot-8, 250-pound, seldom-used reserve to "send a message" against a Hawks team he thought was using illegal screens and referred to his player as a "goon." Chaney earned a five-game suspension.

Hawks coach Phil Martelli and Chaney shook hands and shared a quick laugh before the game, and Martelli said a simple "good game" after they shook hands when it was over.

But Chaney became angry, his voice rising, when questions about the goon game kept coming after the game.

"I didn't call my kids goons, or nobody else goons," Chaney said. "I said every coach in the world sent kids in to take hard fouls and ... the media went crazy on it. I thought we resolved it. Phil and I resolved it. We sent money to Katrina and that's what we did to resolve it. But you want to sing that song? Keep on singing it. Keep on singing it."

Ingram was nearly booed out of the building when he checked in with 3:04 left in the first half, then scored a quick basket on the first possession out of a time-out. Ingram got another earful when he was chewed out by Chaney after a silly foul earned him a spot on the bench midway through the second half.

Ingram scored two points in 7 minutes.

"I kind of expected it," Ingram said. "I think it's over with for the most part. I'm cool with all of it. I don't even worry about it no more."

There were no cheap shots in this one. All the drama in this game was courtesy of constant lead changes, sharp 3-point shooting and a raucous crowd that rekindled memories of the best days of the Big 5.

Temple's Mark Tyndale sandwiched a couple of 3s around one by Dwayne Lee as part of a stretch that featured each team regaining the lead on five straight possessions late in the second half. Antywane Robinson's 3 gave the Owls their biggest lead of the game, 47-41.

Dave Mallon then scored seven straight points on a 3-pointer, a dunk and two free throws to give the Hawks (6-5, 1-1 Atlantic 10) a 48-47 lead.

Jalloh scored 18 of his 22 points in the first half, but he delivered those four points at a clutch time, sinking four straight free throws to make it 57-53. Wayne Marshall then made two free throws and Mardy Collins followed with a driving layup for Temple (6-6, 0-2) to even the score at 57.

With the Hawks coming out of a time-out, Jalloh forced a shot over two defenders, but was bailed by the biggest basket of Ferguson's career, giving Saint Joseph's its seventh straight win over Temple.

"I'm proud of them after being down to come back and get a win," Martelli said.

Collins scored 14 points, and Robinson and Tyndale each had 11 for the Owls.

Jalloh hit six of Saint Joseph's 11 3-pointers in the first half to give the Hawks a 35-29 lead at the break. The Hawks remarkably only had one two-point basket and did not attempt a free throw.

"That was a tough victory against a tough team," Lee said. "A big win is what we needed to get some momentum."

About an hour before the game, Ingram was heckled by Hawks' fans during pre-game warmups. Ingram smiled and laughed as he heard the students' taunts that he was not a basketball player, and that he should be in jail.

While their relationship is still strained, Martelli and Chaney eventually reached a truce and agreed to organize the Atlantic 10's support for the victims of Hurricane Katrina.

"Philadelphia don't let nothing go. You guys don't let nothing go," Chaney said. "I'm a lightening rod in this city and I know it. I love it."

There were a few Temple fans wearing "Goon Squad" shirts, though the packed crowd was decidedly pro-Saint Joe.

While Chaney has tried putting the incident behind him, rarely talking about it since his postgame meltdown last Feb. 22, he felt it directly influenced the refs into calling a string of fouls against the Owls in the final minutes.

"Of course it was. It influenced the officials," Chaney said.

He later added, "Six ... calls at the end of the game went right to them [because of] just the thought of somebody coming close to somebody and starting a problem."
